articles.headline: A.I.G. Unit Said to Be Near Sale to a British Company
articles.snippet: Prudential P.L.C. is expected to acquire the American International Group’s big life insurance business in Asia for about $35.5 billion.
articles.abstract: Prudential P.L.C. is expected to acquire the American International Group’s big life insurance business in Asia for about $35.5 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Prudential P.L.C., the British financial services company, was nearing a deal on Sunday to acquire the American International Group’s big life insurance business in Asia for about $35.5 billion in a move that would help repay taxpayer bailout money, people briefed on the matter said.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Vote Seen as Pivotal Test for Both Iraq and Maliki
articles.snippet: In a country where the normal exit from power has been “the coup or the coffin,” a prime minister faces voters.
articles.abstract: In a country where the normal exit from power has been “the coup or the coffin,” a prime minister faces voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A few months ago, building on genuine if not universal popularity, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki appeared poised to win a second term as Iraq’s prime minister. Now, as Iraqis prepare to vote in parliamentary elections on March 7, his path to another four years in office has become increasingly uncertain, his campaign erratic and, to some, deeply troubling.

articles.headline: Network News at a Crossroads
articles.snippet: As ABC News prepares to cut hundreds of jobs and with news available more places than ever, the future for network news divisions is deeply insecure.
articles.abstract: As ABC News prepares to cut hundreds of jobs and with news available more places than ever, the future for network news divisions is deeply insecure.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABC News is making no secret about what is behind the sweeping staff cuts it now faces: raw survival instinct.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: Rulings Restrict Clean Water Act, Foiling E.P.A.
articles.snippet: Many of the nation’s largest water polluters are outside the E.P.A.’s reach because of disputes on jurisdiction.
articles.abstract: Many of the nation’s largest water polluters are outside the E.P.A.’s reach because of disputes on jurisdiction.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of the nation’s largest water polluters are outside the Clean Water Act’s reach because the Supreme Court has left uncertain which waterways are protected by that law, according to interviews with regulators.
articles.byline: By Charles Duhigg and Janet Roberts

articles.headline: Math of Publishing Meets the E-Book
articles.snippet: E-books are cheaper to produce than print volumes, but consumers may not realize that expenses like overhead and royalties are still in effect, publishers say.
articles.abstract: E-books are cheaper to produce than print volumes, but consumers may not realize that expenses like overhead and royalties are still in effect, publishers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the emerging world of e-books, many consumers assume it is only logical that publishers are saving vast amounts by not having to print or distribute paper books, leaving room to pass along those savings to their customers.

articles.headline: A Column That Lost Its Social Graces
articles.snippet: The Washington that Sally Quinn covers, one governed by convivial elites who battle by day and clink glasses at night, no longer exists.
articles.abstract: The Washington that Sally Quinn covers, one governed by convivial elites who battle by day and clink glasses at night, no longer exists.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Party is over in Washington.

articles.headline: White House Is Rethinking Nuclear Policy
articles.snippet: Aides to President Obama say he will permanently reduce America’s arsenal by thousands of weapons.
articles.abstract: Aides to President Obama say he will permanently reduce America’s arsenal by thousands of weapons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama begins making final decisions on a broad new nuclear strategy for the United States, senior aides say he will permanently reduce America’s arsenal by thousands of weapons. But the administration has rejected proposals that the United States declare it would never be the first to use nuclear weapons, aides said.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Vice Chairman of Fed to Retire, Letting Obama Reshape Board
articles.snippet: President Obama will have three seats to fill at a time when the central bank is weighing how aggressively to reverse its easy-money policy.
articles.abstract: President Obama will have three seats to fill at a time when the central bank is weighing how aggressively to reverse its easy-money policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The vice chairman of the Federal Reserve announced on Monday that he would retire in June, giving President Obama an expanded opportunity to put his stamp on the central bank as it faces a difficult balance between heading off inflation and addressing high levels of unemployment.
